Context:
The text is about a program in Architectural Technology offered by an unspecified college. Here's the key factual information extracted from the text:

- The program covers topics related to AEC industry, including building design, sustainability, building codes and regulations, practice management, technical writing, specifications, cost planning, digital project delivery, digital technologies, computational design, and use of tools like CAD, DPD, BIM, and 3D Visualization and Digital Modelling.
- Students will work in teams on large-scale projects to practice collaboration.
- Enrollment in the program requires completing semester 2 in the summer after the first semester to continue into semester 3 in the fall.
- A co-op Work Placement experience component is available for selected students upon completion of the fourth semester, with limited intake and competitive process.
- The co-op placement takes place from September to December, followed by a blend of in-class and online studies for the final semester allowing students to graduate in April of their final year.
- Career options for graduates include architectural technologist, architectural assistant, and other roles within the AEC industry.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Architectural Technology Program T109 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Architectural Technology program at George Brown College offers various career options for graduates, including but not limited to: architectural technologist, architectural assistant, project director/coordinator, job captain, municipal plans examiner, building inspector, architectural document production, specification writer, property developer, property manager, architectural technologist with builders/developers, site supervisor, and technical representative for building/equipment suppliers.

Graduates of this program have the opportunity to continue their academic career and earn a Master of Architecture Degree from Boston Architectural College (BAC) or The College of Architecture and Design (CoAD) at Lawrence Technological University (LTU), or a Bachelor of Science – Architectural Major (Post Diploma) at Athabasca University. These opportunities are a result of articulation agreements between George Brown College and these institutions.

During their second and/or third year of study, eligible candidates have the chance to apply for a 1-semester Exchange program with the Copenhagen School of Design and Technology (KEA) in Denmark.

Required courses for this program include ARCH 1005: Architectural Technology & Studio 1, ARCH 1014: Canadian Industry Practices, ARCH 1048: Structural Systems 1, ARCH 1050: Visual Communications 1, ARCH 1060: Design Fundamentals, CADE 1012: CAD Drawing 1, COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts, MATH 1139: Mathematics for Arch/IDT 1, ARCH 1006: Architectural Technology & Studio 2, and ARCH 1013: Building Code & Regulations.

Graduates may be eligible for advanced standing in the George Brown College Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program. For more information on advanced standing requirements, see the T314 program webpage.

Context:
The college offers various concentrations in the Architectural Technology program under ARCH codes: 3016 (Digital Technologies), 3032 (Computational Design), 3039 (Architecture), 3040 (Building Science – Renovation and Retrofit), and 3042 (Project Management – Procurement). Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM2000. This extra course does not count towards graduation requirements but will be charged.

Graduates of the Architectural Technology program have opportunities to continue their academic career and transfer credits to:
1. Bachelor of Science – Architectural Major (Post-Diploma) Program at Athabasca University, Alberta, Canada.
2. Master of Architecture with the College of Architecture and Design (CoAD) at Lawrence Technological University (LTU) in Southfield, Michigan, USA.
3. Master of Architecture Degree with Boston Architectural College (BAC) in Boston, Massachusetts, USA.

These opportunities are due to Articulation Agreements signed between George Brown College (GBC) and the respective academic institutions. An additional opportunity includes earning a bachelor's degree in Architectural Technology and Construction Management from the Copenhagen School of Design and Technology (KEA) in Denmark upon completion of two semesters of study and an internship.

The Architectural Technology program focuses on the following learning outcomes:
1. Communicate with clients, contractors, other building professionals and approval authorities.
2. Prepare, read, interpret and revise drawings, and other graphical representations used in building projects.
3. Obtain, analyze, prepare and revise specifications and other project documents used in design and construction.
4. Prepare estimates of time, costs and quantity and participate in the tendering process.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Architectural Technology Program T109 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the roles and responsibilities of an architectural technologist, as well as the tuition fees for domestic and international students at George Brown College for a program starting in Fall 2023 or Fall 2024.

Roles and Responsibilities:
- Participate in estimating time, costs, and quantity for building projects
- Apply principles of building science and mathematics to solve technical problems
- Collaborate with professionals from structural, mechanical, and electrical systems
- Contribute to architectural project design
- Prepare site-planning documents
- Comply with legal and ethical requirements
- Assess buildings for repurposing and renovation
- Ensure workplace safety
- Participate in sustainable design practices
- Use technology to support building projects
- Plan, schedule, and monitor building projects
- Apply business principles to design and building practices

Tuition Fees:
- Domestic students: $4,261.00 for first two semesters (Fall 2023)
- International students: $18,298.00 for first two semesters (Fall 2023)
- Note that fees are subject to change and do not include books or other additional costs.

Financial Assistance:
- The program is approved for OSAP funding for eligible applicants.

Admission Requirements:
- Applicants must have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, including grade 12 English (C or U).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Architectural Technology Program T109 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
* Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent is required.
* Grade 12 English (C or U) is necessary.
* Grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U) is acceptable for Math.
* Mature students (19 years of age or older and no OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math, or consider upgrading.
* Course exemptions are possible with college or university credits. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide.
* International Students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific requirements.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Contact information for the School of Architectural Studies: phone (416-415-5000, ext. 4365), email (architecturalstudies@georgebrown.ca), room D303.
* Additional contact options are available on the International Contact Us page or by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry.
* Information sessions and related programs (Architectural Technician, Interior Design, Honours Bachelor of Technology - Construction Management) can be explored.
